comments:
I have a use case where I pass the provider class that I want to back my IDatamodel:

IDataModel model = DataModelFactory.createDataModel(MyProvider.class);

But because I don't have an extension defined that copies the classname into the id:


   <extension
	point="org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.DataModelProviderExtension">
	 <DataModelProvider
            class="<package>.MyProvider"
            id="<package>.MyProvider"/>	
   </extension

I get the following exception in the log and the IDatamodel comes back null:

*** ERROR ***: Tue Aug 29 14:38:05 EDT 2006    java.lang.RuntimeException: Extension:DataModelProviderExtension Element:DataModelProvider not found for id: <package>.MyProvider
    	at org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.datamodel.DataModelExtensionReader.getProviderExtension(DataModelExtensionReader.java:111)
    	at org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.datamodel.DataModelExtensionReader.getProvider(DataModelExtensionReader.java:154)
    	at org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.datamodel.DataModelFactory.loadProvider(DataModelFactory.java:52)
    	at org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.datamodel.DataModelFactory.createDataModel(DataModelFactory.java:42)
    	at org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.datamodel.DataModelFactory.createDataModel(DataModelFactory.java:89)

Instead of failing, if no extension is defined, the IDatamodel framework should use Class.newInstance() to instantiate the provider.

traces.message: Extension:DataModelProviderExtension Element:DataModelProvider not found for id: <package>.MyProvider
